results.title: Advance Australia
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Dept of the Interior
results.brief_description: An interpretation of the Australian way of life, set against a background showing phases of Australia’s land, cities, natural resources, primary and secondary industries, arts, sports, recreations, and potentialities. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: What's in a Name
results.brief_description: Brian Coyne, a lecturer from Swinburne College, Melbourne, presents an examination of the emergence of the New Right/ Conservatism in Western politics and society, particularly Australia.

results.title: Art makes people
results.creator_credit: Rona Saunders and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A film designed to show that the experience of art education has an important place in the growth of the individual. The film is highly stylised and shows a young child growing and moving through a series of “rooms” encountering various art/educational experiences until she/he emerges to face the world. Includes original music composed and performed by Jim Beattie.

results.title: Touch wood: five Tasmanian woodworkers
results.brief_description: About five men who live in Tasmania and earn their living by working with wood. David Ralph makes small souvenir animals and furniture from horizontal wood; Kevin Perkins makes furniture which allows the natural shape of the wood to be shown; Merv Gray and Peter Mevre make bowls and spheres, and Peter Taylor sculptural pieces.

results.title: Beginning silk screening on fabric (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brenton Holmes, Open College of Further Education (S. Aust.) and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This program demonstrates the basic procedures for silk-screening on to fabric using paper stencils. Building a frame, attaching the silk, preparing stencils and making a two-colour print are shown

results.title: Neon
results.creator_credit: Alex Proyas, Salik Silverstein and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A single-frame time-lapse journey through Sydney, the surrealistic city. Figures dart in and out of the shadows of the night. A kaleidoscope of imagery flies by - incorporates people in subways, cars on freeways, city streets and buildings. The music (by Fad Gadget) drives the images to a tumultuous climax.

results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Production
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.

results.title: The People's land
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films
results.brief_description: In Britain the National Trust has acqired a number of estates and areas of land of historical interest: they include ancient castles, such as the 14th century Bodian castle, a Chiltern village, the famous valley of Dovedale, a number of prehistoric stone circles, 14,000 acres of Westmorland countryside and an extensive area of downland in Sussex. These estates and landmarks are held in public trust forever.
